text: Britain the United States and Japan have
all gone through periods of enormous ly
rapid industrial growth and many of them
in the course of that have ended up
leaving a legacy of pollution that they
have subsequently needed to clean up
China has a different situation it's
going through an industrial revolution
of its own which in some ways is
happening in a more compressed time
frame than those other great powers in
history but it's also got pollution on a
scale that those other great powers
never quite experienced there are
hundreds of thousands of people in China
who are dying every year from pollution
related diseases
the only larger cause of death in China
now than pollution related diseases is
is smoking at 16 of the 25 most polluted
cities in the world or in China then the
area of water pollution they're having
problems in a lot of areas with people
not having access to safe drinking water
that's leading the problems with health
now you also have China confronting a
situation where pollution is not purely
a domestic issue it's an international
issue China last year at least according
to one study has become the largest
emitter of carbon dioxide into the
atmosphere surpassing the United States
Green GDP is really an attempt to arrive
at a true cost of economic growth by not
just looking at a straight GDP figure
but calculating in some of the costs of
environmental pollution and
environmental degradation and resource
use Chinese experts and international
experts have realized there hasn't been
enough focus on the environmental cost
of that growth everyone knows that
pollution is been very serious but if
you can calculate it into the GDP that
really gives people a clearer picture of
what you're really achieving you know if
you actually have a lot of damage to
your own environment and you're losing a
lot of resources are you really growing
at the amount that you think you're
growing the first year's report was
officially released publicly after that
report was published we know from some
people involved in the effort that
provincial leaders among others felt
that this project was a threat to them
especially to some of those in provinces
that have the most heavy industry who
saw their reported growth rates reduced
the most and a lot of them protested
this effort officials and local areas
they're not going to like the idea of a
green GDP because if they continue to do
what they're doing the GDP figures will
go down there are people who probably
preferred the party to go on as usual
and to be able to continue to just
continue to build and make as much money
as possible and so those people have
been resistant you know some people in
the in the local governments have been
resistant to being GDP became more and
more opponents within the system and
eventually they decided to strip this
whole green GDP effort of its of its
official status the official explanation
for discontinuing the green GDP project
as an official project was that the
science behind it is immature the real
explanation I think is that it largely
is a political became a political matter
today provincial leaders are not being
promoted or punished based on what they
do or don't do to protect the
environment but they are being promote
or punished based on the degree to which
they're able to create wealth to which
they're able to ensure social stability
and to create jobs so the incentives for
provincial leaders still tend to favor
economic growth over environmental
protection economic growth is as close
to China comes as having a state
religion one of the prices of the dung
shopping era is that the party has in
some ways really become fixated on
economic growth the whole authoritarian
political system is geared toward
producing not just high economic growth
but in some ways almost ever higher
rates of economic growth the way China's
government has been set up over the last
thirty years really gdp is king if you
can make the gdp grow in your area that
leads to promotions you know it leads to
obviously the more taxes because the
businesses are growing the chinese
leadership is clearly focused on the
pollution problem and on trying to
develop a more environmentally sensitive
economic and political model and they
currently have put in place some quite
ambitious targets for reducing emissions
of various pollutants and also for
reducing the amount of energy that's
required to produce each dollar of GDP
they're actually quite hard targets hard
in terms of fixed and they're very
difficult to meet and so far they've
been unable to meet them but the fact
that they've adopted them and tried to
sort of push them through is is I think
testament to the fact that they're
serious but I think serious questions
still remain as to first of all whether
they're going to be able to achieve
those targets secondly whether the
targets will thoroughly change the
approach to managing the economy or
whether people will figure out how to
comply with the targets without real
changing their underlying behavior
